title: Unify launching for interactive node and check resources before prompt

Closes #889 and #895.

Main changes:
1. Resource check for the interactive node as requested in #889.
2. Check resources before prompt happens.

Tested:
**Interactive nodes**
- [x] `sky gpunode -c test-gpunode --gpus=V100`
- [x] `sky cpunode -c test-gpunode` fails due to node_type mismatch.
- [x] `sky gpunode -c test-gpunode` successfully logged into the cluster.
- [x] `sky gpunode -c test-gpunode --gpus=V100`. Fail due to the resource specification.
- [x] `sky gpunode -c test-gpunode`. Successfully logged into the cluster.

**Prompt**
I ran the following commands step by step:
- [x] `sky launch -c test-resource-check --gpus V100:4 ''`. It launches a gcp instance with 4 GPUs.
- [x] `sky launch -c test-resource-check --gpus V100:4 --num-nodes 2 ''`. Failed before any other info.
- [x] `sky launch -c test-resource-check --gpus V100:4 --cloud aws ''`. Failed before any other info.
- [x] `sky launch -c test-resource-check --gpus V100:8 ''`. Failed before any other info.
- [x] `sky stop test-resource-check` Stop the instance.
- [x] `sky launch -c test-resource-check --gpus V100:4 --num-nodes 2 ''`. Failed before any other info.
- [x] `sky launch -c test-resource-check --gpus V100:4 --cloud aws ''`. Failed before any other info.
- [x] `sky launch -c test-resource-check --gpus V100:8 ''`. Failed before any other info.
- [x] `sky launch -c test-resource-check --gpus V100:4 --cloud gcp ''`. Prompt and successfully launched the cluster.
- [x] `sky gpunode -c test-resource-check` successfully logged into the cluster.

title: Fix Storage Creation
body:
Fixes #796. This should work 100% of the time now (syncing from creating a new bucket).

The bug is that, sometimes, even if the bucket does not exists, `s3.meta.client` call does not error found, so the code thinks that the bucket exists. (https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/blob/master/sky/data/storage.py#L799).

The solution was hence to replace the existing logic of bucket creation.


## Tests

- [x] `sky storage delete michaels-new-bucket-[ID] && sky launch -c hi storage.yaml` many times

title: Sky docker image
body:
# What is this
This PR adds a Dockerfile for the sky cli tool and adds a pointer to a built image that users can easily run on their laptops.

# Why do we need this
During our onboarding sessions, we spend 15 min+ installing sky on users' laptops, and they often run into env specific issues which take up a lot of time when we are simply trying to demo sky to them.

If users already have docker, they can simply run this prebuilt docker image. It contains all aws, gcloud and azure dependencies installed and sky ready to go.

We can pull and run this docker image in `1min 41s` (on m5.xlarge) and requires zero changes to user's env if they have docker installed.

This is not a replacement for installing sky, this is simply for demoing sky.

# How do users use this

If users just want to test drive sky, they can simply run 

```
docker run -td --name sky --rm public.ecr.aws/a9w6z7w5/sky:latest
docker exec -it sky /bin/bash
```

Then they can run `aws configure` or `gcloud init` or `az login` and they should be able to use sky. 

# Open questions

* The currently added link is a public docker image. Anyone can pull it provided they have the URL. This is good and bad. Good because we can easily share sky for people to test drive. Bad because anyone with the link can access it.

* How do we keep the built image updated to master? Can we add a github action? Right now I have built and pushed it manually.

title: Fix sqlite3 rename problem with older version
body:
When we are trying to set up sky on Fabio's laptop with python virtenv, and found the `sky check` complains about renaming the column in the state.db.

After debugging with @infwinston , we found that the problem is caused by an older version of sqlite3 (<3.25) which does not support the syntax for renaming columns.

We remove the usage of the rename function since all our users should already be on our relatively new version of sky (within 2 months). It should be safe to use the new column name without the renaming.

title: Cache head node ip address
body:
The original code tried to reuse a cached head node ip address, but this does not actually work well when multiple processes are accessing the same node. Also the reusing could be dangerous because the head node may already down, so the ip address is actually invalid, and it is not checked in `get_node_ips`.

This PR stores the head node ip address in the database in the right place (so multiple processes can share it once the head node ip is updated), and it performs a quick check of the aliveness of the head node when getting cached IP.

## Tests

- [x] Milestone "100 jobs"
- [x] Smoke tests
- [x] Unit test

title: Fix unnecessary ssh hanging issue on Ray
body:
This PR aims to fix https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/issues/849 by patching Ray autoscaler. Detailed explained in the issue.

We think a simple way is to patch Ray's autoscaler by adding

`self.provider.non_terminated_nodes({})`
before https://github.com/ray-project/ray/blob/6d978ab10ec65da1018790f8605b5b8946e838e5/python/ray/autoscaler/_private/updater.py#L272.

`non_terminated_nodes()` will refresh the states of `self.cached_nodes` and then ray will be able to detect whether the VM is terminated during ssh retry.

----

Regarding testing this PR, unfortunately https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/issues/849 is a little bit hard to reproduce. I tried to manually terminate the VM but this way there won't be gap between VM shutting down and VM state being RUNNING. Not sure if we can simulate preemption signals.

title: Fix Ray autoscaler's failure of gpu auto detection
body:
This PR aims to fix https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/issues/836 which has been a recurring issue to me (happened three times).
This fix is done by checking the #gpu by nvidia-smi and set it manually in `ray start` rather than relying on Ray autoscaler auto-detection.
I tested this PR with running some spot VMs on GCP and they have been through several preemptions. so far the issue seems to be fixed.
But this is a hard-to-reproduce problem. I will try to launch 10 gpu VMs with and without this PR to see if there's difference.

Not sure if we should apply this change to other cloud templates.

title: Enable timeline recording for Sky
body: Timeline is extremely useful for performance analysis and debugging. This PR implements timeline on Sky, tracing timeline of major functions. The overhead of timeline collection is negligible. Here are the APIs: ```python # record a function in the timeline with the function path name @timeline.event def f()... # record a function in the timeline using name='my_name' @timeline.event(name='my_name') def f(): ... # record a block event in the timeline: with timeline.Event(name='event_name'): ... # using a lock with event: with timeline.LockEvent(lockpath): pass ``` You can dumping the timeline to a file by: ```bash #!/bin/bash set -ex mkdir -p temp_logs for i in $(seq -f "%03g" 0 10); do timeline_file_path=timelines/node-"$i".timeline.json # python -m cProfile sky/cli.py spot launch -y -d --cloud=aws node-"$i" --gpus=K80 >node-"$i".log 2>&1 -- "gpustat; echo node $i" & SKY_TIMELINE_FILE_PATH=$timeline_file_path sky spot launch -y -d --cloud=aws node-"$i" >temp_logs/node-"$i".log 2>&1 -- "gpustat; echo node $i" & sleep 1 done wait ``` Here's a very cool screenshot: ## Tests - [x] Milestone "100 jobs" (10 jobs tested) - [x] Run smoke tests (some failed but not related to this PR)

title: [Breaks existing AWS clusters!] Change AWS security group name
body:
**User note: backward incompatibility due to this PR**

This PR **breaks existing AWS clusters** by making them not reusable.  
- If a cluster is STOPPED, any command restarting it (`sky launch`, `sky start`) will launch a NEW
      cluster.  The original cluster will thus be leaked from Sky's perspective.
- If a cluster is UP, a `sky launch` command reusing it will launch a NEW cluster. The
      original cluster will be stopped and thus leaked from Sky's perspective.
- `sky down/stop/exec` on these pre-change clusters still works, if no new clusters
      with the same name have been launched.

Do not upgrade if you care about existing AWS clusters in your `sky status -a`.  

Only upgrade after you have `sky down` them (or making sure manually terminating the leaked ones).  

**This should not affect non-AWS clusters**.

---

PR details:

Using uuid.getnode() is incorrect; observed to collide on Macs.

Tested:
- [x] smoke

title: Make wheel paths stable to avoid disrupting certain running Sky tasks
body:
Fixes #816.  

Now subsequent `sky launch` on the same cluster will not run `setup_commands` at all, if the wheel dir/content didn't change.  Previously all setup_commands are re-run on each `sky launch`, even on the same cluster,  because the ray yaml has a newly made unique local dir for the wheel.

This mitigates but doesn't really fix the root cause, which is that a `sky launch -c existing_cluster` may still disrupt/fail running tasks that uses `sky` the Python package.  The likelihood is lower now.

title: Fix signal handling with stdin=NULL
body:
Closes #817.

Main changes:
1. Fix the ctrl-c, ctrl-z
2. Avoid the tailing subprocess printing additional stuff after the python program is killed by user interruption.

TODO:
- <del>Profile the delay with `process_stream=True`
    It seems the `process_stream=True` will have one line delay for the progress bar, even if I removed the `selectors`. The problem seems to be caused by the `io.TextIOWrapper` or `subprorcess.Popen`. What I tried (all the following have the delay):
    1. Delete everything else in the `log_lib.py` and only left the `io.TextIOWrapper` and `subprorcess.Popen`
    4. Popen with `bufsize=0`
    5. `io.TextIOWrapper` with `write_through=True`
    6. Using `universal_newline=True` for `subprocess.Popen` and remove `io.TextIOWrapper` in our own code, the problem still exists.
    7. The problem can be solved by replacing the `TextIOWrapper` solution by the following manually reading:
    ```python
    Utf8Decoder = codecs.getincrementaldecoder('utf-8')
    decoder = Utf8Decoder(errors='replace')
    while True:
        out = []
        last = proc.stdout.read(4)
        last = decoder.decode(last)
        # Don't loop forever
        if last == '' and proc.poll() is not None:
            break
        while any(l in last for l in ['\n', '\r', '\r\n']):
            # Don't loop forever
            if last == '' and proc.poll() is not None:
                break
            out.append(last)
            last = proc.stdout.read(4)
            last = decoder.decode(last)
        else:
            out.append(last)
        out = ''.join(out)
        print(out, end='', flush=True)
    ```
  8. selectors + the above solution will still cause the problem</del>

title: Fix autoscaler benign assertion by patching
body:
Fixes #807, #754.

Debugging
- modified resource_demand_scheduler to print out detailed vars
- turns out the [assertion](https://github.com/ray-project/ray/blob/releases/1.10.0/python/ray/autoscaler/_private/resource_demand_scheduler.py#L571) is just not correct: When a cluster is fully utilized, a new bundle that comes in looks like `[{'CPU': 0.5, 'GPU': 0.5, 'K80': 0.5}]` and no nodes can fulfill it. This expected.
- Note on [this line](https://github.com/ray-project/ray/blob/releases/1.10.0/python/ray/autoscaler/_private/resource_demand_scheduler.py#L554), `max_to_add = self.max_workers + 1 - sum(node_type_counts.values())`, `max_to_add` (num new nodes that autoscaler wants to add to satisfy this request) is always 0.  This is because we currently do not use autoscaling from the ray autoscaler: the cluster is fully launched at the beginning.  I think that assertion only makes sense assuming new nodes can be added.

Solution: patch this module and comment out the assertion.

Tested:
- modified test_multi_echo to trigger this error: checked that it fails on master and passes on this PR
- smoke tests (unrelated failure: test_spot_storage)
- `for i in $(seq 20); do sky exec test --gpus K80:0.5 'sleep 1' &; done; wait`

title: Fix race condition between job set_state and update_status
body:
This PR is to avoid the following race condition:
1. skylet start job_lib.update_status and get the job status from `ray job status` as PENDING
2. The generated ray program called `set_job_started` and change the job status in jobs.db to be `RUNNING`.
3. skylet set the job status in jobs.db to be PENDING.

title: Fix TPU resource leak
body:
Thanks @concretevitamin for raising this issue. The TPU resource leak can be reproduced by executing `sky launch` twice where tpu name is randomly generated each time and `gcp-tpu-delete.sh` is overwritten, causing the first one to be leaked.
As multi-node TPU is not supported yet and blocked [here](https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/blob/master/sky/task.py#L251), we don't really need a random generated TPU name at this moment. I think we can safely switch back to use cluster name. 
however, we should come back to multi-node scenario soon.

title: Fix storage tests failing with parallel runners
body:
The bucket name used in the storage smoke tests uses `int(time.time())` to create a unique name for buckets to be created:

https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/blob/881e6cc39f440975dfaff724da436744c6bf0f0a/tests/test_smoke.py#L464

This is flaky when tests are run in parallel because two parallel runners may use the same bucket id, creating a race condition. This PR changes the id to `f'sky-test-{time.time_ns()}'`, which has a significantly less chance of collision. 

A more complex solution is to use the id of the worker [(in ~slaveinput~ `workerinput`)](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest-xdist/issues/47#issuecomment-187891183) to accurately label buckets, but using nanoseconds keeps the tests simple yet functional.

title: Add BERT and Resnet spot examples
body: This PR adds two examples for BERT QA and Resnet spot training. The former is based on a huggingface [BERT-QA example](https://github.com/huggingface/transformers/tree/main/examples/pytorch/question-answering) which integrates checkpointing and wandb logging pretty well. The latter is based on our `resnet_distributed_torch` example. The examples mount sky storage at `/checkpoint` and will periodically save models to the persistent storage. Once preempted, sky spot recovers the VM which loads the ckpt and resumes training. Note: users need to fill in their wandb key in the yaml to run the two examples smoothly. The BERT-QA training on V100 looks like this. (different colors mean different spot VMs) The two preemptions were real and the VMs were killed by AWS. This is the latest figure. the exp continues to run for almost 2 days and survived for 5 preemptions!!

title: Fix sky spot failover bug
body:
This PR removes a filter in awc cli which may cause bugs preventing sky spot from failing over to other regions. Because aws cli failed to capture the instance id when the status is `terminated` rather than `stopping/stopped`. so that the status table is not cleaned up (basically normal sky down failed) and sky spot can't fail over to other regions.

After discussion with @Michaelvll , we think remove the filter should be okay because the cluster name should be identifiable.

```
ubuntu@ip-172-31-90-228:~$ sky down sky-beab-weichiang-7
Terminating 1 cluster: sky-beab-weichiang-7. Proceed? [Y/n]: 
Terminating 1 cluster ━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━   0% -:--:--E 05-03 04:53:12 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:2238] Failed to terminate sky-beab-weichiang-7. If you want to ignore this error and remove the cluster from from Sky's status table, use `sky down --purge`.
E 05-03 04:53:12 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:2238] **** STDOUT ****
E 05-03 04:53:12 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:2238] 
E 05-03 04:53:12 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:2238] **** STDERR ****
E 05-03 04:53:12 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:2238] 
E 05-03 04:53:12 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:2238] An error occurred (InvalidParameterCombination) when calling the TerminateInstances operation: No instances specified
E 05-03 04:53:12 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:2238] 
Terminating cluster sky-beab-weichiang-7...failed. Please check the logs and try again.
```

title: Fix security group mismatch issue with autostop
body:
See #779 for details.

Closes #779

The cause of the original issue was #731 generates security group name based on local machine with autoscaler. However, the autoscaler of the head node generates a different security group name because it is running on the remote machine. This confuses Ray autoscaler.

Thanks @concretevitamin @Michaelvll for discovering and investigating into this issue!

I could not repro the issue anymore in #779 with this fix.

title: Fix sky cancel for on-prem mode
body:
~~`sky cancel` fails to kill the user processes when on-prem mode is used as `ps --forest` does not list processes with different users.~~
~~Replace it with `pstree` to find all descendent processes.~~


~~Also, replace `kill -s 0` with `ps -p` to check the liveness of process as `kill -s 0` can [return 1](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/3043978/how-to-check-if-a-process-id-pid-exists) even if the process is running.~~

-----
`sky cancel` fails to kill the user processes when on-prem mode is used as `ps --forest` does not list processes with different users.
This PR implements a python based subprocess_daemon with [psutil](https://psutil.readthedocs.io/en/latest/#) for 1) readability and 2) alternative command `pstree` is not available on GCP.  
However, the problem for on-prem is not fully resolved because `sky cancel` still fails to kill the parent process with `ray stop` for some reason. might need @michaelzhiluo to debug this.

-----

This PR also fixed https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/issues/835 by checking if the target process exists or not to avoid generating infinite processes in sky spot case.

TODOs
- [x] Add cancel tests for three clouds
- [x] Pass cancel tests for three clouds 
- [ ] Add a cancel test for on-prem (this is a bit complicated as we don't have an automatic script for setting up on-prem yet, cc @michaelzhiluo )

title: Reuse sky wheels for efficiency
body:
This PR ensures we will not rebuild wheels every time for every provision. The wheel is only rebuilt if it is older than the sky codebase. A classic "compare, update and clone" consistency protocol is used to eliminate race conditions when launching multiple clusters at the same time.

This makes sky wheels build ~480x faster for users (benchmark locally). (Unfortunately it is not the bottleneck in provision, but could still be critical as our repo grows bigger and bigger).

```
Before caching: 1.787348985671997s
After caching: 0.0037221908569335938s
```

I already tested it with single and multiple nodes.

body:
## Description
Adds On-Premise support for Sky. Allows for multiple users to access the same Ray cluster and share resources over multiple nodes.

New Commands:
`sky local status` - Lists local clusters. `sky status` lists both cloud and local clusters.
`sky local launch` - Setup Sky services on Local cluster. Run by system admin.

This PR is to add a prototype for fault-tolerant spot instance training. For more details, please refer to the [design docs](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1vt6yGIK6wFYMkHC9HVTe_oISxPR90ugCliMXZKu762E/edit).

title: Fix descendant processes termination for sky cancel
body:
Closes #757.

The reason for the GPU process not being killed is that the previous `pkill -P` does not kill all the descendant processes, i.e. it only kills the child process but not the grandchildren (47055 is killed but not 47096). We now kill all the processes by manually [finding all the descendants](https://superuser.com/a/822450).
```
  47048 ?        Ss     0:00      0    73  2558   604  0.0      \_ /bin/sh -c /bin/bash -i /tmp/sky_app_g6ba5x2m
  47055 ?        S      0:00      0   705  9230  4916  0.0      |   \_ /bin/bash -i /tmp/sky_app_g6ba5x2m
  47096 ?        Sl    18:24      0  1975 50101904 22511544 35.8      |       \_ python3 -u models/official/resnet/resnet_main.py --use_tpu=False --mode=train --train_batch_size=256 --train_steps=25000 --
```

Tested:
- [x] `sky launch -c test-cancel ./examples/resnet_app.yaml -d; sleep 180; sky cancel test-cancel-a` and `ssh` into the instance, check the `gpustat` that GPU memory is correctly freed.

title: Add Imagenet Benchmark
body: To test out how well goofys performs for a real deep learning workload, I made this benchmark. ## ImageNet Dataset Information ### Stats * 1M training images, and 50K val images * Size: about 150 GB. * S3 bucket in us-east-2 [URL](https://s3.console.aws.amazon.com/s3/buckets/sky-imagenet-data?region=us-east-2&tab=objects) ### Dataset hierarchy datasets/ | ILSVRC2012/ | imagenet/ | meta.bin |   |   -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | --   |   |   | train/ | class0/ | ~1000 images (~150KB)   |   |   |   | class1/ | ~1000 images (~150KB)   |   |   |   | class2/ | ~1000 images (~150KB)   |   |   |   | ... |     |   |   |   | class999/ | ~1000 images (~150KB)   |   |   |   |   |     |   |   | val/ | class0/ | 50 images (~150KB)   |   |   |   | class1/ | 50 images (~150KB)   |   |   |   | ... |     |   |   |   | class1000/ | 50 images (~150KB) ## Resnet-18 It is possible to reach a reasonable speed with s3 (image-based) training as the EBS by increasing the number of data load workers. * 1.4x slower than the same number of loaders on EBS. * 64 workers on S3 get a similar speed with 4 load workers on EBS. ![Screen Shot 2022-04-20 at 10 21 40 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6753189/164288483-1bbfc508-2308-4a12-a8c5-49d7e03b7b67.png) More details can be found in [result sheet](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1DW3yhWZ-jqQGCINzNhbcntx31R1WwRv3TULewTPP6Sg/edit#gid=836651687) / [Wandb](https://wandb.ai/michaelvll/sky-imagenet?workspace=user-michaelvll).
